thread.title: Vice President Mike Pence Visits Former Dachau Nazi Concentration Camp « CBS New York
thread.title_full: Vice President Mike Pence Visits Former Dachau Nazi Concentration Camp « CBS New York

title: Vice President Mike Pence Visits Former Dachau Nazi Concentration Camp « CBS New York
text:
Vice President Mike Pence Visits Former Dachau Nazi Concentration Camp February 19, 2017 7:56 PM Filed Under: Dachau , Mike Pence , politics Head of Dachau Concentration Camp Memorial Site Gabriele Hammermann (2L), US Vice President Michael Richard Pence (3L), former prisoners of Nazi concentration camp Dachau, Abba Naor from Israel (3R), Karen Pence (2R) and Charlotte Pence (R) walk at the former Nazi concentration camp of Dachau, southwestern Germany, on February 19, 2017. (THOMAS KIENZLE/AFP/Getty Images) 
DACHAU, Germany (AP) — U.S. Vice President Mike Pence paid a somber visit to the site of the Dachau concentration camp on Sunday, walking along the grounds where tens of thousands of people were killed during World War II. 
Pence was joined by his wife, Karen, and the couple’s 23-year-old daughter, Charlotte, as they toured the exhibits at the former concentration camp that was established by the Nazis in 1933 near Munich. 
“Moving and emotional tour of Dachau today,” Pence tweeted Sunday. “We can never forget atrocities against Jews and others in the Holocaust.” Moving and emotional tour of Dachau today. We can never forget atrocities against Jews and others in the Holocaust. pic.twitter.com/69GWN2DKDF 
— Vice President Pence (@VP) February 19, 2017 
The vice president was accompanied by Abba Naor, a survivor of the camp, and other dignitaries as he passed through the wrought-iron gate bearing the inscription, “Arbeit macht frei,” or “Work sets you free.” The Pences placed a wreath beneath the International Memorial at the center of the camp, toured the barracks and viewed the ovens inside the crematorium. 
The Pences also stopped at religious memorials at the site and later attended a church service on the camp’s grounds. 
The concentration camp for political prisoners and Jews near Dachau was the first such facility in Germany. In 1935 other groups, among them Jehovah’s Witnesses, gays and emigrants, were sent there. After a larger facility was built, more political prisoners and more than 11,000 German and Austrian Jews were sent there in 1938. In time, more than 200,000 people from across Europe were held at Dachau and subsidiary camps, and more than 40,000 died. The camp was liberated by U.S. forces in April 1945. During the tour today of Dachau, survivor Abba Noar recalled to me the horrors of the Holocaust, "then the American troops came." pic.twitter.com/WuVo7Jtk3L 
— Vice President Pence (@VP) February 19, 2017 
Former Vice President Joe Biden visited Dachau in 2015. 
Making his first overseas trip as vice president, Pence spoke to foreign diplomats and defense officials at the Munich Security Conference on Saturday and met with German Chancellor Angela Merkel and other world leaders. 
Shortly after his arrival in Brussels later Sunday, Pence said the American people appreciate the nation’s alliance with Belgium and he’s looking forward to his meetings with European Union and NATO leaders on Monday.
